list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Let $f$ and $g$ be functions such that $g(x) = 3f(x-2)+1$, for
$x \in \mathbb{R}$.
The graph of $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ after the following
transformations:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\text{a vertical stretch by a factor of $k$, followed by} \\
&\text{a horizontal translation of $a$ units, followed by} \\
&\text{a vertical translation of $b$ units}. \\
\end{aligned}
$$


- Write down the value of:
  
  - $k$;
  - $a$;
  - $b$. [3]



Let $h(x) = -2g(x)$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.
The point P$(3,4)$ on the graph of $g$ is mapped to point Q on the graph
of $h$.

- Find the coordinates of Q. [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{k = 3}$
  - $\answer{a = 2}$
  - $\answer{b = 1}$

- The graph of $h$ is obtained from the graph of $g$ using two
transformations.
  Their geometric descriptions are:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{transformation $1$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\text{vertical stretch by a factor of $2$;} \\[6pt]
  \text{transformation $2$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\text{reflection in the $x$-axis.}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we apply the transformations $1$ and $2$ to P, we find
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/81adf7f8-647c-479f-bd0f-8f896cd0c7c3/images/fe8c659b-613c-4fc0-a165-b07d10509323/1510a052325892668888784527ddbb81323a45d9.svg)


  Hence the coordinates of Q are
$\answer{(3,-8)}$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Let $f(x) = 0.2e^{x+2} - 4$, for $-3 \leq x \leq 2$.

- On the following grid, sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. [3]

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/4d1c7bf9-8d2a-4f7a-945e-f582b73039b2/219ede634589aee775d4d590dd79b30ff5c63914.svg)


- Find the coordinates of:
  
  - the $x$-intercept;
  - the $y$-intercept. [2]



The graph of $f$ is reflected in the $x$-axis, then translated 1 unit in the direction of the positive $x$-axis and 2 units in the direction of the positive $y$-axis to obtain the graph of a function $g$.

- Find $g(x)$.   [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we draw the graph of $y = f(x)$ for $-3 \leq x \leq 2$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/0c8cb343-6319-4c4b-bd01-6881dfb5c2ff/a0ce7feb5a9182c2d088b3711cfba75a324b8033.svg)


- 
  - Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.2em} 0.2e^{x+2} - 4 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &\approx 0.996 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are
$\answer{(0.996,0)}$
  - Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
    &= 0.2e^{0+2} - 4 \hspace{0.4em} \\[7pt]
    &\approx -2.52\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the
$y$-intercept are
$\answer{(0,-2.52)}$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.5em} g(x) &= -f(x-1) + 2 \\[6pt]
  &= -\big[0.2e^{(x-1)+2} - 4\big] + 2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -0.2e^{x+1} + 6}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Let $f(x) = x^3$ and $g(x) = 5(x-2)^3$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.
The graph of $g$ can be obtained from the graph of $f$ using two transformations.

- Give a full geometric description of each of the transformations. [2]


The graph of $g$ is translated by 4 units in the direction of the positive $x$-axis, and 1 unit in the direction of the negative $y$-axis to give the graph of a
function $h$.
The point P$(1,1)$ on the graph of $f$ is translated to point Q on the
graph of $h$.

- Find the coordinates of Q. [4]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{transformation $1$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{vertical stretch by a factor of $5$}} \\[6pt]
  \text{transformation $2$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{translation of 2 units in the direction of the positive $x$-axis.}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we apply the transformations $1$ and $2$ from part (a), and transformation $3$ from part (b) to P, we find
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e1a61284-0cae-4301-9a9e-89a7e58d9d56/images/b28c508c-6131-4aee-a6fd-a87b131e9f21/577066d1f46b6880207621796d732b7e8ac43d46.svg)


  Hence the coordinates of Q are
$\answer{(7,4)}$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Let $f(t) = 3t^2 + 27$, where $t > 0$.
The graph of a function $g$ is obtained when the graph of $f$ is
transformed by

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\text{a stretch by a scale of\hspace{0.05em} $\dfrac{1}{9}$ \hspace{0.05em}parallel to the $y$-axis, followed by} \\
&\text{a horizontal translation of 4 and a vertical translation of -5}\\
\end{aligned}
$$


- Find $g(t)$, giving your answer in the form $a(t - b)^2 + c$.
[4]


A particle moves along a straight line so that its velocity in
m s$^{-1}$, at time $t$ seconds, is given by
$g(t)$.

- Find the distance the particle travels between $t = 7$ and
$t = 10$.   [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} g(t) &= \dfrac{1}{9}f(t - 4) - 5  \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{9}\big[3(t - 4)^2 + 27\big] - 5 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{1}{3}(t - 4)^2 -2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The distance the particle travels between $t = 7$ and $t = 10$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.8em} \text{distance} &= \int_7^{10} \left|g(t)\right| \mathrm{d}t \\[2pt]
  &= \int_7^{10} \left|\dfrac{1}{3}(t - 4)^2 -2\right| \mathrm{d}t \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= 15 \text{ m}}  \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 6
Question 7
list.content:
Let $f(x) = a(x+1)(x+5)$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where
$a \in \mathbb{Z}$. The following diagram shows part of the graph of
$f$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b2539ad3-5cb1-47b4-82fb-0f17c7d9b8b2/images/5a0794f4-b904-4254-9ade-c72ff4d130c0/c560b93b90031104353dd8752d2c6976f60f1751.svg)


The graph of $f$ has $x$-intercepts at $(p,0)$ and $(q,0)$, and a
$y$-intercept at $(0,-10)$.

- 
  - Write down the value of $p$ and the value of $q$.
  - Find the value of $a$. [6]


- Find the equation of the axis of symmetry. [2]

- Find the coordinates of the vertex. [3]


The graph of a function $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ by a
reflection in the $y$-axis, followed by a translation of 2 units in the direction of the positive $y$-axis. The point P$(-2,6)$ on the graph of $f$ is mapped to point Q on the graph of
$g$.

- Find the coordinates of Q. [4]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{p = -5}$  and
$\answer{q = -1}$
  - Using the coordinates of the $y$-intercept, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f(0) &= -10 \hspace{5.5em} \\[6pt]
    a(0+1)(0+5) &= -10  \\[6pt]
    5a &= -10  \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{a = -2}
    $$


- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.8em} f(x) &= -2(x+1)(x+5) \\[6pt]
  &= -2(x^2+6x+5) \\[5pt]
  &= -2x^2-12x-10\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the axis of symmetry
formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.5em} x &= -\dfrac{b}{2a} \\[6pt]
  x &= -\dfrac{(-12)}{2(-2)} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{2.2em} \answer{x = -3}
  $$

- Using the method of completing the square, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.7em} f(x) &= -2x^2-12x-10 \\[6pt]
  &= -2\big[x^2+6x\big] - 10 \\[6pt]
  &= -2\big[(x+3)^2 - 9\big] - 10 \\[6pt]
  &= -2(x+3)^2 + 8\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of the vertex
are  $\answer{(-3,8)}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.9em} \text{transformation $1$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\text{reflection in the $y$-axis} \\
  \text{transformation $2$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\text{translation of two units upwards}
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  If we apply the transformations $1$ and $2$ to P, we find
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b2539ad3-5cb1-47b4-82fb-0f17c7d9b8b2/images/5463dadf-bc47-4d8c-a965-e2b73e47474d/e1df7f8211664f00389891c42cbdf0bb7d3cdd9a.svg)


  Hence the coordinates of Q are
$\answer{(2,8)}$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Let $f(x) = 3x^2 + 12x + 9$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- For the graph of $f$, find:
  
  - the $y$-intercept;
  - the $x$-intercepts. [4]



The function $f$ can be written in the form $f(x) = a(x-h)^2+k$.

- Find the values of $a$, $h$ and $k$. [5]

- For the graph of $f$, write down:
  
  - the coordinates of the vertex;
  - the equation of the axis of symmetry. [2]



The graph of a function $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ by a reflection in the $x$-axis, followed by a translation of 4 units in the direction of the positive $y$ axis.

- Find $g(x)$, giving your answer in the form
$g(x) = px^2 + qx + r$.  [4]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Evaluating $f(x) = 3x^2 + 12x + 9$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{5em} f(0) &= 3(0)^2 + 12(0) + 9 \\[6pt]
    &= 9 \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the $y$-intercept is
$\answer{\mathrm{A}(0,9)}$
  - Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.5em} 3x^2 + 12x + 9 &= 0 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
    x^2 + 4x + 3 &= 0 \\[7pt]
    (x+3)(x+1) &= 0 \\[7pt]
    x &= -3,\hspace{0.25em}-1 \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the
$x$-intercepts are
$\answer{\mathrm{B}(-3,0)}$
and
$\answer{\mathrm{C}(-1,0)}$

- Using the method of completing the square, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.9em} f(x) &= 3x^2 + 12x + 9 \\[6pt]
  &= 3\big[x^2 + 4x\big] + 9 \\[6pt]
  &= 3\big[(x + 2)^2 - 4\big] + 9 \\[6pt]
  &= 3(x + 2)^2 - 3 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{a = 3,\hspace{0.25em} h = -2}$
and  $\answer{k = -3}$
- 
  - $\answer{(-2,-3)}$
  - $\answer{x = -2}$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4em} g(x) &= -f(x)+4 \\[6pt]
  &= -(3x^2 + 12x + 9)+4 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -3x^2 - 12x - 5}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Let $f(x) = 2x^2 + 4x + p$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where
$p \in \mathbb{Z}$.

- The equation $f(x) = 0$ has two equal roots.
  
  - Write down the value of the discriminant of $f$.
  - Show that $p = 2$. [3]


- For the graph of $f$, find:
  
  - the equation of the axis of symmetry.
  - the coordinates of the vertex; [4]


- Write down the solution to the equation $f(x) = 0$. [1]

- The function $f$ can be written in the form $f(x) = a(x-h)^2 + k$.
Find
the values of $a$, $h$ and $k$. [5]

- The graph of a function $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ by a
reflection
in the $x$-axis. Find the coordinates of the vertex of the graph of
$g$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{\triangle  = 0}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2em} \triangle  &= b^2 - 4ac \\[4pt]
    0 &= 4^2 - 4(2)(p) \hspace{0.5em} \\[5pt]
    0 &= 16 - 8p \\[5pt]
    16 &= 8p \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{p = 2} \hspace{2.9em}
    $$


- 
  - Using the axis of symmetry formula, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    x &= -\dfrac{b}{2a} \\[6pt]
    x &= -\dfrac{4}{2(2)} \hspace{1.4em} \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{x = -1} \hspace{2.9em}
    $$

  - Evaluating $f(x)=2x^2 + 4x + 2$ for $x = -1$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.2em} f(-1) &= 2(-1)^2 + 4(-1) + 2 \\[8pt]
    &= 0\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the vertex are
$\answer{(-1,0)}$

- $\answer{x=-1}$
- Using the method of completing the square, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} f(x) &= 2x^2 + 4x + 2 \\[6pt]
  &= 2\big[x^2 + 2x\big] + 2 \\[6pt]
  &= 2\big[(x+1)^2 - 1\big] + 2 \\[6pt]
  &= 2(x+1)^2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{a = 2,\hspace{0.25em} h = -1}$
and  $\answer{k = 0}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.2em}  g(x) &= -f(x) \\[6pt]
  &= -2(x+1)^2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of the vertex of
the graph of $g$ are
$\answer{(-1,0)}$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Let $f(x) = 2x^2-8x+6$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Write down the value of $f(0)$. [1]

- Solve the equation $f(x) = 0$. [3]


The function $f$ can be written in the form $f(x) = a(x-h)^2+k$.

- Find the values of $a$, $h$ and $k$. [5]

- For the graph of $f$, write down:
  
  - the coordinates of the vertex;
  - the equation of the axis of symmetry. [2]



The graph of a function $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ by a reflection in the $x$-axis, followed by a translation of 1 unit to the right and 3 units up.

- Find $g(x)$, giving your answer in the form
$g(x) = px^2+qx+r$.   [4]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{f(0) = 6}$
- Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2x^2-8x+6 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  x^2-4x+3 &= 0 \\[7pt]
  (x-1)(x-3) &= 0 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{6.8em} \answer{x = 1,\hspace{0.25em}3}
  $$

- Using the method of completing of square, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1em} f(x) &= 2x^2-8x+6 \\[6pt]
  &= 2\big[x^2-4x\big]+6 \\[6pt]
  &= 2\big[(x-2)^2-4\big]+6 \\[6pt]
  &= 2(x-2)^2-2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{a = 2,\hspace{0.25em}h=2}$
and  $\answer{k=-2}$
- 
  - $\answer{(2,-2)}$
  - $\answer{x = 2}$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.4em} g(x) &= -f(x-1)+3 \\[6pt]
  &= -\big[2((x-1)-2)^2-2\big]+3 \\[6pt]
  &= -2(x-3)^2+5 \\[6pt]
  &= -2(x^2-6x+9)+5 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -2x^2+12x-13}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
Let $f(x) = 2(x-1)^2-8$, for $x\in\mathbb{R}$.

- Show that $f(x) = 2x^2-4x-6$. [2]

- For the graph of $f$:
  
  - write down the coordinates of the vertex;
  - write down the $y$-intercept;
  - find both $x$-intercepts. [7]


- Hence sketch the graph of $f$. [3]


Let $g(x) = 6x^2$, for $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
The graph of $f$ may be obtained from the graph of $g$ using the
following three transformations:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1em} & \bullet\text{ a compression of scale factor $a$ in the $y$-direction, followed by} \\
& \bullet\text{ a horizontal translation of $h$ units, followed by} \\
& \bullet\text{ a vertical translation of $k$ units.}
\end{aligned}
$$


- Find the values of $a, h$ and $k$.   [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.9em} f(x) &= 2(x-1)^2-8 \\[6pt] 
  &= 2(x^2-2x+1)-8 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2x^2-4x-6}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - $\answer{(1,-8)}$
  - $\answer{\text{P}(0,-6)}$
  - Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    2x^2-4x-6 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x^2-2x-3 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    \hspace{0.8em} (x+1)(x-3) &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &= -1,\hspace{0.25em}3\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the $x$-intercepts
are
$\answer{\text{A}(-1,0)}$
and
$\answer{\text{B}(3,0)}$

- If we sketch the graph of $f$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/defd40b3-8635-4c03-88d0-1ea05c7ccca1/images/42674bdd-229f-43b4-bb47-2584f965f100/8374016b8a888aa9fc9466667cfab6ca4babdde2.svg)


- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= ag(x-h)+k \\[6pt]
  2(x-1)^2 - 8 &= a\big[6(x-h)^2\big]+k \\[6pt]
  2(x-1)^2 - 8 &= 6a(x-h)^2+k \hspace{2.5em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we
find
$\answer{a = 1/3,\hspace{0.25em} h = 1}$
and  $\answer{k = -8}$

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
Let $f(x) = ax^3 + bx^2 + cx  +  d$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where
$a,b,c,d \in \mathbb{Q}$. The diagram below shows part of the graph of
$y = f(x)$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d78a10f2-621e-426c-91f2-9dea87dbacc5/images/89842500-91d4-4b78-a494-6ce2510b4acf/f2e9d58912ae2f10d7fdf9d12ee3b7594c2c45fb.svg)



- Using the information shown in the diagram, find the values of $a$,
$b$, $c$ and $d$.[4]

- Let $g(x) = -\dfrac{3}{4}f(-2x+1)$.
  
  - Find the coordinates of the points where the graph of $y = g(x)$
intercepts the $x$-axis.
  - Find the $y$-intercept of the graph of $y = g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- From the diagram, we see that the roots of the polynomial equation
$f(x) = 0$ are $-3$, $-1$ and $3$.
  Hence, using the factor theorem, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= a(x-3)(x+1)(x+3) \\[6pt]
  &= a(x^2-9)(x+1) \\[6pt]
  &= a(x^3 + x^2 - 9x - 9) \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we substitute
$x = 0$ in the expression $(1)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.6em} f(0) &= a(0^3 + 0^2 - 9(0) - 9) \\[12pt]
  -3 &= -9a \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(0) = -3$}] \\[6pt]
  a &= \dfrac{1}{3}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we substitute $a = 1/3$ in the
expression $(1)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= \dfrac{1}{3}(x^3 + x^2 - 9x - 9) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{3}x^3 + \dfrac{1}{3}x^2 - 3x - 3 \hspace{1.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{a = b = \dfrac{1}{3}}$
and  $\answer{c = d = -3}$
- 
  - Solving the equation $g(x) = 0$ for $x$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    -\dfrac{3}{4}f(-2x + 1) &= 0 \\[6pt]
    f(-2x + 1) &= 0 \\[12pt]
    -2x + 1 &= -3,\hspace{0.25em} -1,\hspace{0.25em} 3 \hspace{4em} \\[12pt]
    -2x &= -4,\hspace{0.25em} -2,\hspace{0.25em} 2 \\[12pt]
    x &= -1,\hspace{0.25em}1,\hspace{0.25em}2\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence
the coordinates of the $x$-intercepts of the graph of $y = g(x)$
are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \answer{(-1,0),\hspace{0.25em}(1,0),\hspace{0.25em}(2,0)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Evaluating $y=g(x)$ for $x = 0$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{10.9em} y &= g(0) \\[10pt]
    &= -\dfrac{3}{4}f(2(0)+1) \\[6pt]
    &= -\dfrac{3}{4}f(1) \\[6pt]
    &= -\dfrac{3}{4}\hspace{-0.2em}\left[\dfrac{1}{3}(1)^3 + \dfrac{1}{3}(1)^2 - 3(1) - 3\right] \\[4pt]
    &=-\dfrac{3}{4}\hspace{-0.2em}\left[-\dfrac{16}{3}\right] \\[10pt]
    &= 4\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the $y$-intercept of the graph of
$y = g(x)$ is
$\answer{\mathrm{P}(0,4)}$

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
Part of the graph of a function, $f$, is shown in the following diagram. The graph of $y=f(x)$ has two horizontal asymptotes, $y=4$ and $y=-2$.
The $x-$intercept of $f(x)$ is $a$ and the $y-$intercept is $-b$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0ac0e6e0-05ca-462b-9d93-d5a8fc982532/images/8f8afd09-e0d3-46b2-842f-52575d6cd5ec/question.png)


Consider the function $g(x)=|f(|x|)|$.

- Sketch the graph of $y=g(x)$ on top of the image above, labelling any new axis intercepts, in terms of $a$ and $b$, and giving the equation of any new asymptotes. [3]

- Find the possible values of $r$ such that $(g(x))^2=r$ has exactly two solutions.[3]
list.markScheme:
- The inner absolute value, $f(|x|)$, has the effect of reflecting the part of $f(x)$ to the right of the $y-$axis in the $y$-axis.
  The outer absolute value, $|f(x)|$, reflects the part of the graph below the $x$-axis in the $x$-axis and combines it with the existing positive part of the function. Therefore, we have:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0ac0e6e0-05ca-462b-9d93-d5a8fc982532/images/2fee9019-6645-41e0-b0ca-a5b67a484d6f/ans1v2.png)


- A sketch of $(g(x))^2$ is shown below
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0ac0e6e0-05ca-462b-9d93-d5a8fc982532/images/64bc0b61-1acf-4d6a-97ca-801e246cd00b/ans2.png)


  The $y-$intercept is now at $b^2$ and the new asymptote is at $y=4^2$. $(g(x))^2$ has two solutions between the two dashed lines, hence $b^2<r<16$.
  Additionally, there are two solutions when $r=0$. Hence there are two solutions to the equation when

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  &\answer{b^2<r<16 \text{ and }r=0} \tag*{\textbf{A1A1A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
Consider the function $g(x)=ax^3+bx^2+cx+d$, where $x\in \mathbb{R}$ and
$a$, $b$, $c$, $d \in \mathbb{R}.$

- 
  - Write down an expression for $g'(x)$.
  - Hence, given that $g^{-1}$ does not exist, show that
$b^2-3ac>0.$[3]



Consider the function
$f(x)=\dfrac{x^3}{2}+3x^2+6x+\dfrac{9}{2}$

- 
  - Show that $f^{-1}$ exists.
  - $f(x)$ can be written in the form $p\hspace{0.05em}(x+2)^3+q$,
where $p$, $q\in \mathbb{R}$. Find the value of $p$ and the
value of $q$.
  - Hence, find $f^{-1}(x)$.[7]



The graph of $f(x)$ may be obtained by transforming the graph of $y=x^3$
using a sequence of three transformations.

- State each of the transformations in the order in which
they are applied.[3]

- Sketch the graphs of $y=f(x)$ and $y=f^{-1}(x)$ on the same
set of axes, indicating the points where each graph crosses the
coordinate axes.[4]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Taking the derivative with respect to $x$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    g'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\hspace{0.1em} \big[ ax^3+bx^2+cx+d \big] \\[12pt]
    &\answer{= 3ax^2+2bx+c} \end{aligned}
    $$

  - As $g^{-1}$ does not exist, the graph of $g$ should have two
turning points. Thus, the derivative has a strictly positive
discriminant, this is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \big[\text{discriminant of $g'$}\big] &> 0 \\[12pt]
    (2b)^2 - 4(3a)(c) &> 0 \hspace{3.5em} [\triangle  = b^2 - 4ac] \\[12pt]
    4b^2 - 12ac &> 0 \\[12pt]
    &\hspace{-1.25cm}\answer{b^2-3ac > 0} \end{aligned}
    $$


- 
  - Using part (a) (ii), we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    (3)^2-3\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\left(6\right) & \ngtr 0. \end{aligned}
    $$

    Therefore, by the contrapositive statement to part (a) (ii), we
deduce $f^{-1}$ exists.
  - Factorizing the expression for $y=f(x)$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f(x) &= \dfrac{1}{2}\left(x^3+6x^2+12x+9\right) \\[10pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{2}\left(x^3+6x^2+12x+8+1\right)  \\[10pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{2}\left(x+2\right)^3 + \dfrac{1}{2}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Therefore
$\answer{p=\dfrac{1}{2}, \, q=\dfrac{1}{2}}$
  - If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[12pt]
    f(y) &= x \\[10pt]
    \dfrac{1}{2}(y+2)^3+\dfrac{1}{2} &= x \\[10pt]
    (y+2)^3 &= 2x - 1 \\[12pt]
    y+2 &= \sqrt[3]{2x-1} \\[12pt]
    &\hspace{-10.5mm}\answer{f^{-1}(x) = \sqrt[3]{2x-1} - 2} \end{aligned}
    $$


- We get the following transformations

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{transformation $1$}&: \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{horizontal translation $2$ units left}} \\[10pt]
  \text{transformation $2$}&:
  \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{vertical stretch by a factor of $\dfrac{1}{2}$}}\\[10pt]
  \text{transformation $3$}&: \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{vertical translation $\dfrac{1}{2}$ units up}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Note: The horizontal translation can be performed in any step but
the
vertical stretch should be performed before the vertical
translation.
- Using the shape of a cubic function, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bad00ea0-0b26-414f-a642-5211980e8eb3/images/6f61d4f5-598d-4c89-a21d-4c9ec4d63076/79b23cf27cdbbbaba59cb5e2eee4c41cd47b395a.svg)

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
The following diagram shows the graph of
$y=\arctan(2x-3)+\dfrac{3\pi}{4}$ for $x\in \mathbb{R}$,
with asymptotes at $y=\dfrac{\pi}{4}$ and $y=\dfrac{5\pi}{4}$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/94f32658-f1f8-4e8a-a7ec-64540cbb0149/images/f7349dc1-1bf4-4e25-a560-7f6b11100f20/081334c23d135e25efc729fff5cf10e0f4fe7363.svg)



- Describe a sequence of transformations that transforms the graph of
$y=\arctan x$ to the graph of $y=\arctan(2x-3)+\dfrac{3\pi}{4}$ for
$x\in \mathbb{R}$.[3]

- Show that
$\arctan p - \arctan q \equiv \arctan \left(\dfrac{p-q}{1+pq}\right)$.[3]

- Verify that
$\arctan(x+2)-\arctan(x+1) = \arctan\left( \dfrac{1}{(x+1)^2+(x+1)+1}\right)$.[3]

- Using mathematical induction and the results from part (b) and
(c), prove that[8]


  $$
  \sum_{r=1}^n \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) = \arctan(n+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4} \hspace{0.8em} \text{for } n\in \mathbb{Z}^{+}.
  $$
list.markScheme:
- The function can be expressed as
$y=\arctan\left(2\left(x-\dfrac{3}{2}\right)\right)+\dfrac{3\pi}{4}$,
hence we get the following transformations in order

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{transformation $1$}&: \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{horizontal stretch by a factor of $\dfrac{1}{2}$}} \\[10pt]
  \text{transformation $2$}&:
  \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{horizontal translation $\dfrac{3}{2}$ units right}}\\[10pt]
  \text{transformation $3$}&: \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{vertical translation $\dfrac{3\pi}{4}$ units up}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Note that the vertical shift, which is transformation $3$, can also be performed before the horizontal transformations.
- Using the compound angle identity, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \tan\left(\arctan p - \arctan q \right) &= \dfrac{\tan(\arctan p)-\tan(\arctan q)}{1+\tan(\arctan p)\tan(\arctan q)} \\[12pt]
  &=\dfrac{p-q}{1+pq} \\[12pt]\\
  \intertext{Finally, taking the $\arctan$ on both sides}\\
  &\hspace{-2.85cm}\answer{\arctan p - \arctan q \equiv \arctan \left(\dfrac{p-q}{1+pq}\right)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the formula from part (b), we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arctan(x+2)-\arctan(x+1) &= \arctan\left(\dfrac{(x+2)-(x+1)}{1+(x+2)(x+1)}\right)\\[12pt]
  &= \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{((x+1)+1)(x+1)+1}\right)\\[12pt]
  &\hspace{0.2em}\answer{=\arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{(x+1)^2+(x+1)+1}\right)} \end{aligned}
  $$

- Let $\mathrm{P}(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{r=1}^n \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) &= \arctan(n+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4} \hspace{3em} \big[\,\text{for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$}\,\big]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using mathematical induction, we will prove that $\mathrm{P}(n)$
holds for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$.
  Base case. For $n = 1$, from part (a), we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{(1)^2+1+1}\right) &= \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right) \\[10pt]
  &= \arctan(2)-\arctan(1) \hspace{3em} \big[\text{by part (b,c)}\big]\\[12pt]
  &= \arctan(2)-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence P$(1)$ holds.
  Inductive hypothesis. We assume that $\mathrm{P}(k)$
holds for some $k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{r=1}^k \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) = \arctan(k+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4} \hspace{0.5em} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  for some $k \geq 1$.
  Inductive step. To show that $\mathrm{P}(k+1)$ holds,
we need to show that

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{r=1}^{k+1} \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) = \arctan(k+2)-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we add the $k+1$ term to both sides of the equation (IH), we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{r=1}^{k+1} \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) &= \arctan(k+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4} + \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{(k+1)^2+(k+1)+1}\right)\\[10pt]
  \big[\text{by part (c)}\big]\hspace{3em} &= \arctan(k+2) - \arctan(k+1) + \arctan(k+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\\[12pt]
  &= \arctan(k+2)-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence $P(k+1)$ holds
as well.
  Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
  Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$.
